OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS, UMPQUA NATIVE PLANT PARTNERSHIP WILL DEVELOP AND EXPAND ITS CAPACITY AS AN ORGANIZATION BY STRENGTHENING LOCAL LEADERSHIP, SETTING CONCRETE GOALS, AND FACILITATING COLLABORATION BETWEEN MEMBERS. THESE ACTIONS WILL RESULT IN A MORE ROBUST LOCAL ECONOMY FOR NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS, DIVERSE GENETICS FOR NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS PLACED OUT ON THE LANDSCAPE, AND A RICH SOURCE OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR GROWERS AND USERS OF NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS.

THE MISSION OF THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) IS TO CONSERVE THE LAND AND WATER ON WHICH ALL LIFEDEPENDS. AT ITS CORE, THE MISSION IS ONE OF BENEFITING HUMANS AND NATURE THROUGH BETTER STEWARDSHIP OF OURLAND AND WATER RESOURCES, INCLUDING WORKING WITH MANAGERS TO GENERATE NEW SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENTPRACTICES. TNCS WORK IS DIRECTLY IN LINE WITH THE BLMS DIRECTIVES TO ADDRESS THE CLIMATE CRISIS, RESTOREBALANCE ON PUBLIC LANDS AND WATERS, ADVANCE ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE, AND INVEST IN A CLEAN ENERGY FUTUREAND BLM WYOMINGS PRIORITIES TO PROTECT BIODIVERSITY, INCREASE RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND HELPLEVERAGE NATURAL CLIMATE SOLUTIONS, CONTRIBUTE TO CONSERVING AT LEAST 30 PERCENT OF OUR LANDS AND WATERS BYTHE YEAR 2030  ENGAGE COMMUNITIES OF COLOR, LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND RURAL AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIESTO ENHANCE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES RELATED TO NATIVE SEED PRODUCTION AND RESTORATION  AND USE THE BESTSCIENCE AND DATA AVAILABLE TO MAKE DECISIONS. ONE OF THE CORE STRATEGIES OF THE WYOMING CHAPTER OFTNCS CURRENT STRATEGIC PLAN IS TO IMPROVE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION IN ORDER TO IMPROVE LANDSCAPERESILIENCE TO CHANGE  THEREBY PROTECTING THE BIODIVERSITY AND HUMAN LIVELIHOODS THAT RELY ON THISECOSYSTEM  AND TO REDUCE LOSS OF SOIL CARBON STORAGE DUE TO THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES AND THEASSOCIATED INCREASED RISK OF WILDFIRE.

A KEY COMPONENT OF SUCCESSFUL RECLAMATION RESTORATION IS THE PERFORMANCE OF DESIRABLE SPECIES IN THE FACE OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOLOGICAL STRESSORS (DRASTIC SOIL DISTURBANCE, INVASIVE WEED COMPETITION, ETC.). IDEAL PLANT MATERIAL SELECTIONS WILL MAINTAIN THE GENETIC AND ECOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF A FIELD SITE WHILE ESTABLISHING WELL UNDER AMBIENT CONDITIONS AND BEING COMPLEMENTARY TO MANAGEMENT GOALS (WILDLIFE HABITAT, SOIL STABILIZATION, LIVESTOCK FORAGE, SPECIES DIVERSITY) AND TO ADDITIONAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (GRAZING, HERBICIDE FOR INVASIVE WEED CONTROL). THIS COMPLEX SET OF CHARACTERISTICS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT TO PLANT MATERIALS IN NORTHEAST WYOMING DUE TO A SET OF CHALLENGES AND STRESSORS INCLUDING RAPID SPREAD OF INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, HIGH WILDFIRE FREQUENCY, HIGH-DENSITY ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, AND INCREASED EXURBAN (SMALL-ACREAGE) SUBDIVISION. THESE STRESSORS HAVE IMPACTED THE POWDER RIVER BASIN REGION FOR YEARS, AND RECLAMATION FROM LONG-TERM LEGACIES OF THESE ISSUES IS STILL NEEDED.

THE VAST "SAGEBRUSH SEA" OF THE WESTERN US PROVIDES ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR THE IMPERILED GREATER SAGEGROUSE, VALUABLE AND ICONIC BIG GAME SUCH AS MULE DEER AND PRONGHORN, AND NUMEROUS OTHER SPECIES. IT IS  ALSO ESSENTIAL TO THE RANCHING ECONOMY AND WAY OF LIFE OF MANY RURAL COMMUNITIES THAT RELY ON PUBLIC AND  PRIVATE GRAZING LAND. YET THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM IS RAPIDLY CHANGING AND DECLINING IN AREAS DUE TO NONNATIVE SPECIES INVASIONS, CHANGES IN FIRE REGIMES, AND SURFACE DISTURBANCES.  THE WYOMING PORTION OF THE SAGEBRUSH SEA IS THE MOST INTACT OF THE REMAINING SAGEBRUSH HABITAT BOTH IN  EXTENT AND HABITAT QUALITY. HOWEVER, THIS REGION FACES THE LOOMING THREAT OF INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS  EXPANSION AND INCREASED DEVELOPMENT FOOTPRINTS. SUCCESSFUL MAINTENANCE AND RESTORATION OF NATIVE PLANT  COMMUNITIES, SUCH AS SAGEBRUSH AND NATIVE FORBS AND PERENNIAL GRASSES, IS KEY TO SAFEGUARDING THE  RESILIENCE AND ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS OF THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM: PROVIDING HABITAT FOR BIODIVERSITY,  SUPPLYING FORAGE FOR LIVESTOCK, STORING SOIL CARBON AS PART OF NATURAL CLIMATE SOLUTIONS, AND PROTECTING  HUMAN COMMUNITIES FROM WILDFIRES. SUCCESSFUL RESTORATION OF DISTURBED, BURNED, AND ANNUAL-INVADED LAND  IS CRITICAL TO MAINTAIN THESE FUNCTIONS AND REDUCE THE RISK OF FUTURE ANNUAL GRASS INVASION AND WILDFIRE.  TO ENSURE THAT RESTORATION IS DONE WITH THE RIGHT SEED MATERIALS, IN THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAYS, WE PROPOSE  THREE INTER-RELATED AREAS OF WORK TO: (1) INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES FOR USE IN  RESTORATION IN WYOMING, (2) IMPROVE RESTORATION SUCCESS OF NATIVE PLANTS USING SEED-ENHANCEMENT  TECHNOLOGY, AND (3) CONVENE PARTNERS TO SHARE KNOWLEDGE AND INFORMATION RELATING TO NATIVE PLANT  RESTORATION IN WYOMING.  THERE IS CURRENTLY A SHORTAGE OF NATIVE SEEDS AVAILABLE IN WYOMING FOR RESTORATION, AND THIS IS AN  IMPEDIMENT TO SCALING UP RESTORATION TO MEET THE ANTICIPATED LARGER DEMAND IN THE FUTURE. TO INCREASE  NATIVE SEED AVAILABILITY, WE NEED TO BE ABLE TO GERMINATE AND GROW SEEDS COMMERCIALLY SO THEY ARE  AVAILABLE IN THE LARGE QUANTITIES NEEDED FOR RESTORATION AND AT A PRICE THAT DOESN'T PROHIBIT THEIR USE.  HOWEVER, MOST HIGH-PRIORITY RESTORATION SPECIES HAVE UNKNOWN SEED DORMANCY. WE WILL STUDY SEED  DORMANCY FOR DESIRED SPECIES, WITH THE GOAL OF INFORMING SEED-BASED RESTORATION, SEED INCREASE OPERATIONS,  AND NURSERY PRODUCTION TO ENABLE WIDER AVAILABILITY AND INCLUSION OF THESE SPECIES IN RESTORATION EFFORTS  THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE. RESTORATION SUCCESS FOR SAGEBRUSH - A FOUNDATIONAL AND CRUCIAL FORAGE SPECIES - IS OFTEN VERY LOW, WITH THE  GREATEST FAILURE AT THE SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT PHASE. WHILE SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT WILL ALWAYS BE A  CHALLENGE IN ARID LANDS, THE "SEED TECHNOLOGY" APPROACH HOLDS SOME PROMISE TO IMPROVE ESTABLISHMENT  SUCCESS. SEED TECHNOLOGIES INVOLVE MODIFYING SEEDS TO OVERCOME ECOLOGICAL ESTABLISHMENT BARRIERS. WE  ARE WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH A COMMERCIAL SEED TECHNOLOGY COMPANY TO DEVELOP AND TEST PROTOTYPES  FOR SAGEBRUSH SEED TECHNOLOGY. IN THE LONG-TERM, WE WILL NEED SEED TECHNOLOGIES TO BE EFFECTIVE, SCALABLE,  AND COMMERCIALLY-PRODUCED IF THEY ARE GOING TO INCREASE LARGE-SCALE RESTORATION EFFECTIVENESS AT THE LEVEL  NEEDED BY THE BLM AND OTHER LAND MANAGERS.  OUR THIRD AREA OF WORK INVOLVES PROMOTING THE SHARING AND SPREAD OF KNOWLEDGE ON RESTORATION SUCCESSES,  FAILURES, BEST PRACTICES, AND FUTURE INFORMATION NEEDS. TO THIS END, WE WILL CONVENE AND HOST A WYOMING  SAGEBRUSH RESTORATION SUMMIT, BRINGING TOGETHER A BROAD SET OF PRESENTERS, DISCUSSION LEADERS, AND  ATTENDEES FROM MANAGEMENT, RESEARCH, CONSULTING, AND OTHER RELEVANT ARENAS. IN ADDITION TO PROMOTING  KNOWLEDGE-SHARING, THIS KIND OF GATHERING CAN CATALYZ

SESSILEFLOWER INDIAN PARSLEY (CYMOPTERUS SESSILIFLORUS) IS A RECENT ADDITION TO THE WYNDD  SPECIES OF CONCERN LIST IN WYOMING. PREVIOUSLY KNOWN AS ALETES SESSILIFLORUS (THEOBALD ET AL.  1964, HARTMAN 2006), THIS PLANT IS ONLY KNOWN FROM NORTHWESTERN NEW MEXICO, AND ONE COUNTY  IN EACH OF ARIZONA, COLORADO, AND WYOMING. IN WYOMING, IT HAS BEEN FOUND IN FREMONT COUNTY  AND TWO OF THE THREE KNOWN POPULATIONS ARE ON BLM LANDS. ALL WYOMING POPULATIONS ARE  KNOWN FROM SPECIMEN COLLECTIONS, MOST OF WHICH HAD PREVIOUSLY BEEN MISIDENTIFIED AS OTHER  SPECIES. SESSILEFLOWER INDIAN PARSLEY IS CURRENTLY RANKED G3/S1 (GLOBALLY VULNERABLE/STATE  CRITICALLY IMPERILED; NATURESERVE 2020). THE POLLINATION ECOLOGY OF C. SESSILIFLORUS IS UNKNOWN. CYMOPTERUS SESSILIFLORUS IS A PERENNIAL  WITH AN UMBEL INFLORESCENCE OF SMALL, YELLOW FLOWERS. CYMOPTERUS SPECIES MAY SELF-POLLINATE  BUT CROSS-POLLINATING USING INSECTS IS TYPICALLY PREFERRED TO PROMOTE HIGH GENETIC DIVERSITY  (SCHLESSMAN AND GRACEFFA 2002, KOUL ET AL. 1993). THE DECLINE OF NATIVE POLLINATORS (POTTS ET AL.  2010) WILL LIKELY HAVE A DETRIMENTAL EFFECT ON THE REPRODUCTION OF THIS RARE PLANT SPECIES AND MAY  LIMIT POPULATIONS. WE PROPOSE TO INVESTIGATE THE DISTRIBUTION OF CYMOPTERUS SESSILIFLORUS AND ITS  INSECT POLLINATORS. LEARNING MORE INFORMATION ABOUT CYMOPTERUS SESSILIFLORUS WILL PROVIDE  INFORMATION IF THIS PLANT IS PETITIONED FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND PROVIDE  DATA TO THE BLM TO HELP MAKE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. WE PROPOSE TO SURVEY THE KNOWN C. SESSILIFLORUS OCCURRENCES, AND CONDUCT SEARCHES FOR NEW  OCCURRENCES IN THE BLM LANDER FIELD OFFICE TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO WYOMING BLM FOR THEIR  DECISIONS ON WHETHER OR NOT TO ADD THE PLANT TO THE BLM SENSITIVE SPECIES LIST. THESE SURVEYS  WOULD ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO WYNDD'S KNOWLEDGE OF THE SPECIES AND THE CALCULATION OF STATE  RANKING.

1. STATEMENTS OF NEED: WINWARD'S GOLDENWEED (ERICAMERIA WINWARDII) IS KNOWN FROM THREE POPULATIONS  IN THE WORLD - ONE IN WYOMING AND TWO IN IDAHO. ITS GLOBAL HERITAGE RANK POSTED BY NATURESERVE IS  GLOBALLY CRITICALLY IMPERILED (G1). ITS STATE RANK IN BOTH IDAHO AND WYOMING IS STATE CRITICALLY IMPERILED  (S1). ERICAMERIA WINWARDII HAS BEEN COMPLETELY SURVEYED IN IDAHO. THOUGH SURVEY IN WYOMING HAS  BEEN EXTENSIVE (FERTIG 2012), LARGE SEGMENTS OF POTENTIAL HABITAT HAVE NOT BEEN ADDRESSED. THE IDAHO  POPULATIONS ARE NEAR THE STATE LINE, AND THE WYOMING POPULATION IS ABOUT 50 MILES TO THE SOUTHEAST, WITH  UNSURVEYED WYOMING HABITAT BETWEEN THEM. THREATS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED FOR THE SPECIES IN IDAHO THAT  ELEVATE THE VALUE OF CURRENT AND COMPLETE WYOMING INFORMATION.  2. PURPOSE: THIS FINAL PRODUCT WILL CONTRIBUTE BASELINE INFORMATION TO THE BLM SPECIES SPECIAL STATUS  PROGRAM AND TO MANAGEMENT PLANNING. 3. OBJECTIVES: SYSTEMATIC SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED OF ERICAMERIA WINWARDII ACROSS POTENTIAL HABITAT IN  WYOMING TO CONFIRM ITS ISOLATION FROM IDAHO POPULATIONS OR TO EXPAND KNOWN DISTRIBUTION.  4. METHODS/APPROACH: THE KNOWN WYOMING LOCATION WILL BE REVISITED TO CONFIRM INTACT CONDITIONS, SEEK  ANY EVIDENCE OF TRENDS OR CHANGES TO SPECIES' EXTENT AND LOCAL DISTRIBUTIONS, SPECIES' NUMBERS, HABITAT  REQUIREMENTS, LIFE HISTORY INFORMATION, AND POTENTIAL THREATS. THEN, SURVEY TARGETS BETWEEN IDAHO AND  WYOMING POPULATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIED BASED ON THE SURFACE GEOLOGY AND PHOTOINTERPRETATION. ANY NEW  LOCATIONS WILL BE DOCUMENTED WITH VOUCHER SPECIMENS AND BY PHOTOGRAPHING THE SPECIES ACROSS THE  ENCOUNTERED RANGE OF PHENOLOGICAL STAGES, LIFE HISTORY AND HABITAT CONDITIONS. RESULTS OF THE 2023  FIELDWORK WILL BE PRESENTED INTO A DETAILED STATUS REPORT UPDATING SPECIES' STATUS IN WYOMING. 5. TIMETABLE OR MILESTONES: PLANS WILL BE COMMUNICATED BEFORE THE START OF FIELDWORK (SPRING 2023), AND  OUTCOME WILL BE COMMUNICATED AFTER THE FIELD SEASON. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PREPARED OF SURVEY RESULTS.  THE TIMETABLE HAS FIELDWORK PREPARATION BY SPRING 2023 AND FINAL REPORT SUBMITTAL IN SPRING 2024.

THE UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON BOTANIC GARDENS RARE CARE PROGRAM PARTNERS WITH STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES ON THE LONG-TERM CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF RARE AND SENSITIVE PLANT SPECIES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. AS PART OF THIS PARTNERSHIP, RARE CARE COORDINATES A RARE PLANT MONITORING PROGRAM TO COLLECT INFORMATION ON THE STATUS OF RARE PLANT POPULATIONS ON PUBLIC LANDS IN WASHINGTON STATE AND MAINTAINS AN EX SITU SEED BANK THAT SUPPORTS REINTRODUCTION AND RESTORATION OF CRITICALLY IMPERILED SPECIES. RARE PLANT MONITORING IS CARRIED OUT BY VOLUNTEERS WHO VISIT KNOWN POPULATIONS OF RARE PLANTS AT SITES ACROSS WASHINGTON STATE, COLLECT DATA ON THE POPULATION AND ITS HABITAT, AND SUBMIT MONITORING REPORTS THAT ARE DISTRIBUTED TO THE WASHINGTON NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AND LAND MANAGERS AT PUBLIC AGENCIES. THE EX SITU SEED PROGRAM INCLUDES SEED COLLECTIONS FROM WILD POPULATIONS OF RARE PLANTS, SEED CURATION AND GERMINATION TESTING. RARE CARE WILL MONITOR 130 POPULATIONS OF RARE PLANTS STATEWIDE, TRAIN 30 VOLUNTEERS IN THE RARE PLANT MONITORING PROTOCOLS, COLLECT SEEDS FROM 10 POPULATIONS TO ADD TO THE EX SITU COLLECTION, AND CONDUCT 15 GERMINATION TESTS ANNUALLY.

THE POTENTIAL OF HARVESTER ANTS TO CONSUME SEEDS INTENDED FOR NATIVE PLANT RESTORATION IS ESPECIALLY CONCERNING IN THE CONTEXT OF GRASSLAND EXPANSION RESULTING FROM ACCELERATED FIRE CYCLES IN AREAS ONCE DOMINATED BY SAGEBRUSH. THIS CONVERSION OF HABITAT MAY ALLOW HARVESTER ANTS TO COLONIZE AREAS THAT WERE HISTORICALLY UNSUITABLE FOR NESTING BY PROVIDING OPEN SPACES WITH A RICH FOOD SUPPLY (ROBERTSON AND ROBERTSON 2020). VEGETATION STATE TRANSITIONS THAT ALLOW FOR INCREASED COLONIZATION BY HARVESTER ANTS MAY PROVE COSTLY TO NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WHOSE SEEDS ARE READILY CONSUMED BY ANTS. AS HARVESTER ANT COLONY DENSITY INCREASES, THE THREAT OF SEED PREDATION TO RESTORATION EFFORTS COULD INCREASE AS WELL. GIVEN THE COSTLY AND LABOR-INTENSIVE NATURE OF RESTORATION PROJECTS AND THE VARIABLE SUCCESS OF THESE EFFORTS TO DATE, IT IS ESSENTIAL TO CONSIDER THE POSSIBLE ROLE OF SEED PREDATION BY HARVESTER ANTS. UNDERSTANDING THE EXTENT TO WHICH SEED PREDATION BY HARVESTER ANTS INFLUENCES RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND IMPROVE RESTORATION OUTCOMES

W.I.N. OPERATES IN EVERY WATERSHED IN OREGON THAT LIES WEST OF THE CASCADES CREST EITHER DIRECTLY, OR VIA NETWORK PARTNERS THAT INCLUDE OVER 100 MOU-SIGNING FEDERAL, STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES AS WELL AS MYRIAD NGO PARTNERS WHO ARE ALL FOCUSED ON HABITAT RESTORATION, NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITY PRESERVATION AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENT. FOR THE LAST 20 YEARS, THE MISSION OF W.I.N. IS TO CREATE, MAINTAIN AND STRENGTHEN COLLABORATIVE MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION, AND AWARENESS OF INVASIVE SPECIES OF CONCERN IN NORTHWEST OREGON AND SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON. W.I.N. ACCOMPLISHES OUR MISSION BY ACHIEVING NUMEROUS OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO:1. DEVELOP AND COORDINATE AWARENESS, EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAMS IN COOPERATION WITH THEOREGON/WASHINGTON INVASIVE SPECIES COUNCILS, OREGON/WASHINGTON DEPARTMENTS OF AGRICULTURE, OREGON/WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION, SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICTS, WATERSHED COUNCILS, FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-PROFITS, AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTNERS.2. SERVE AS A CONDUIT OF INFORMATION RELATED TO INVASIVE WEED CONTROL FOR PARTNERS AND THE PUBLIC IN NORTHWEST OREGON AND SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON.3. SUPPORTING THE TECHNICAL AND ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY OF COOPERATIVE WEED MANAGEMENT AREAS.4. PROMOTE EFFECTIVE COUNTY WEED DISTRICTS AND/OR LOCAL MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS.5. IDENTIFY AND LEVERAGE EXISTING RESOURCES TO ASSIST IN IMPLEMENTING INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.6. SECURE NEW FUNDING TO SUPPORT PRIORITY PROJECTS AND LOCAL IMPLEMENTATION CAPACITY WITHIN NORTHWEST OREGON AND SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON.7. PROVIDE LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND MEMBERS OF THE WESTERN INVASIVES NETWORK WITH INFORMATION REGARDING THE AUTHORITIES, CAPABILITIES, MISSIONS AND SERVICES OF THE PARTNERS.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS IAE'S MISSION BY DEVELOPING AND COMMUNICATING SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON COLUMBIA YELLOWCRESS AND THE SURROUNDING PLANT COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS DEVELOPING/IMPROVING EFFECTIVE POPULATION ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THIS PROJECT MAY ALSO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR 3-4 COLLEGE-LEVEL INTERNS. INTERNS GAIN DIRECT FIELD EXPERIENCE AND GET THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL, WHICH HELPS PREPARE THEM FOR EMPLOYMENT WITH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES.THE KLAMATH FALLS FIELD OFFICE HAS BEEN PROTECTING NATIVE PLANTS AND THEIR ASSOCIATED HABITAT FOR MANY YEARS AND WOULD LIKE TO CONTINUE THESE EFFORTS TO MAINTAIN, ENHANCE AND RESTORE A BLM SENSITIVE PLANT COLUMBIA YELLOWCRESS (RORIPPA COLUMBIAE) AND ITS HABITAT. THESE EFFORTS ARE PART OF THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY FOR REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION WITHIN THE KLAMATH FALLS RESOURCE AREA. IN ORDER TO RETAIN THIS LOCAL SPECIES,THE KFRA HAS PARTNERED WITH LOCAL EXPERTS ON THIS SPECIES FROM THE INSTITUTE OF APPLIED ECOLOGY. FUNDING IS NEEDED FOR THIS MULTIPHASE, THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO PROCEED. PHASE ONE WILL INVENTORY SUITABLE HABITAT, COLLECT, CLEAN AND STORE SEED FOR SHORT-TERM USE. THE SECOND PHASE INCLUDES GROWOUT OF THE SEED AND OUTPLANTING OF SEEDLINGS WITHIN SUITABLE HABITAT AND MONITORING WITHIN THE AREA. OUTPLANT AREAS WILL BE DETERMINED & SERVE AS REFUGIA FOR THIS SPECIES TO GROW AND PROLIFERATE IN AREAS PROTECTED FROM GROUND DISTURBING ACTIVITIES (I.E., EXCLOSURES). THIS PROJECT WOULD ALSO MITIGATE SOIL AND VEGETATION DISTURBANCE BY INCREASING NATIVE SEED PRODUCTION IN ORDER TO BE USED ON RESTORATION SITES AS NEEDED TO IMPROVE NATIVE HABITAT AND PREVENT NOXIOUS WEED ESTABLISHMENT AND SPREAD WITHIN DISTURBED AREAS.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ESSENTIAL, LOCALLY SOURCED, NATIVE PLANT SPECIES (IN THE FORM OF SEEDS OR BULBS) FOR ENHANCING AND RESTORING NATURAL COMMUNITIES IN WETLANDS, PRAIRIES, AND OAK SAVANNAH IN THE WEST EUGENE WETLANDS. IT WILL BE A KEY PART OF JOINT FUNDING THAT INCLUDES STAFF PROVIDED BY THE CITY OF EUGENE (CITY) AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) TO IMPLEMENT ACTIONS WHICH PROTECT, CONSERVE, ENHANCE, AND RESTORE POPULATIONS OF SPECIAL STATUS SPECIES AND THEIR ENDANGERED WETLAND AND PRAIRIE ECOSYSTEM IN THE SOUTHERN WILLAMETTE VALLEY.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS MADE AND ENTERED INTO BY THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, NEVADA STATE OFFICE (BLM), AND NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, THE RECIPIENT, FOR THE PURPOSE OF SUPPORTING THE NDA/BLM SEED PROGRAM PARTNERSHIP TO ENCOURAGE THE FARMING COMMUNITY TO IMPLEMENT LOCALLY ADAPTED NATIVE SEED INTO PRODUCTION REGIMENS, THEREBY INCREASING THE SUPPLY AND AVAILABILITY OF SEED, AND IMPLEMENTING AN OUTREACH/EDUCATION CAMPAIGN TASKED WITH INCREASING THE AMOUNT OF SOURCE IDENTIFIED MATERIAL ON THE MARKET.

THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT A ROBUST STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM THAT DEPLOYS STAFF, WORK CREWS, AND VOLUNTEERS FROM FRIENDS OF NEVADA WILDERNESS THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF NEVADA TO MAP, MONITOR, AND COLLECT DIVERSE FORBS AND GRASS SEEDS FOR RESTORATION OF WILDLIFE HABITATS AND REHABILITATION AFTER FIRES.
